question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Phil has 7 green marbles and 3 purple marbles in a bag. He removes a marble at random, records the color, puts it back, and then repeats this process until he has withdrawn 6 marbles. What is the probability that exactly three of the marbles that he removes are green? Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest thousandth.
inference:
Let G be the event that a green marble is drawn, and P be the event that a purple marble is drawn.
The probability of drawing a green marble is P(G) = 7/10.
The probability of drawing a purple marble is P(P) = 3/10.
We want to find the probability that exactly 3 of the 6 marbles drawn are green.
This is a binomial probability problem. The number of ways to choose 3 green marbles out of 6 draws is given by the binomial coefficient:
$$\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6!}{3!(6-3)!} = \frac{6!}{3!3!} = \frac{6 \times 5 \times 4}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = 20$$
The probability of getting exactly 3 green marbles in 6 draws is given by the binomial probability formula:
$$P(X=3) = \binom{6}{3} (P(G))^3 (P(P))^{6-3} = \binom{6}{3} \left(\frac{7}{10}\right)^3 \left(\frac{3}{10}\right)^3 = 20 \times \left(\frac{7}{10}\right)^3 \times \left(\frac{3}{10}\right)^3$$
$$P(X=3) = 20 \times \frac{343}{1000} \times \frac{27}{1000} = 20 \times \frac{343 \times 27}{1000000} = 20 \times \frac{9261}{1000000} = \frac{185220}{1000000} = 0.18522$$
Rounding to the nearest thousandth, we get 0.185.
Final Answer: $\boxed{0.185}$
ground_truth: There is a $\left( \frac{7}{10} \right) ^3 \left( \frac{3}{10} \right) ^3 = \frac{9261}{1000000}$ probability that 3 particular marbles out of 6 will be green and the rest will be purple. There are also  $\binom{6}{3}=20$ ways to choose which 3 out of the 6 are the green ones. Because these ways are all mutually exclusive, we multiply to get the probability that we're looking for: $20 \cdot \frac{9261}{1000000}\approx \boxed{.185}$.

question:
Let G be the event that a green marble is drawn, and P be the event that a purple marble is drawn.
The probability of drawing a green marble is P(G) = 7/10.
The probability of drawing a purple marble is P(P) = 3/10.
We want to find the probability that exactly 3 of the 6 marbles drawn are green.
This is a binomial probability problem. The number of ways to choose 3 green marbles out of 6 draws is given by the binomial coefficient:
$$\binom{6}{3} = \frac{6!}{3!(6-3)!} = \frac{6!}{3!3!} = \frac{6 \times 5 \times 4}{3 \times 2 \times 1} = 20$$
The probability of getting exactly 3 green marbles in 6 draws is given by the binomial probability formula:
$$P(X=3) = \binom{6}{3} (P(G))^3 (P(P))^{6-3} = \binom{6}{3} \left(\frac{7}{10}\right)^3 \left(\frac{3}{10}\right)^3 = 20 \times \left(\frac{7}{10}\right)^3 \times \left(\frac{3}{10}\right)^3$$
$$P(X=3) = 20 \times \frac{343}{1000} \times \frac{27}{1000} = 20 \times \frac{343 \times 27}{1000000} = 20 \times \frac{9261}{1000000} = \frac{185220}{1000000} = 0.18522$$
Rounding to the nearest thousandth, we get 0.185.
Final Answer: $\boxed{0.185}$

There are also  $\binom{6}{3}=20$ ways to choose which 3 out of the 6 are the green ones. Because these ways are all mutually exclusive, we multiply to get the probability that we're looking for: $20 \cdot \frac{9261}{1000000}\approx \boxed{.185}$.
